_meta.name: Nursing Lecture Template System - Example Data
_meta.description: Sample content for all 20 slide template types

content.subtitle: NURS 301 · Module 1: Clinical Foundations
content.instructor: Dr. Sarah Chen, DNP, RN, CCRN

content.title: Physical Assessment Techniques
content.subtitle: Module 1 · Assessment Basics
content.intro_text: A comprehensive physical assessment is the foundation of quality nursing care. This systematic approach ensures no critical findings are missed.
bullet_points: Inspection: Visual examination of body areas for abnormalities
Palpation: Using touch to assess texture, temperature, and tenderness
Percussion: Tapping to assess underlying structures
Auscultation: Listening with stethoscope for body sounds

content.quote: The good physician treats the disease; the great physician treats the patient who has the disease.

steps.title: Assess
steps.description: Collect comprehensive patient data through interview, observation, and examination

steps.title: Diagnose
steps.description: Analyze data to identify nursing diagnoses and patient problems

steps.title: Plan
steps.description: Set measurable goals and select evidence-based interventions

steps.title: Implement
steps.description: Execute the care plan with proper documentation

steps.title: Evaluate
steps.description: Assess patient outcomes and modify plan as needed

content.title: Nursing Workforce Statistics
content.subtitle: Module 1 · Professional Context
content.source: Bureau of Labor Statistics, Occupational Outlook Handbook 2024

content.title: Case Study: Acute Assessment
content.subtitle: Module 1 · Clinical Application
content.patient_info:
Mr. Johnson, 72 y/o male

PMH: HTN, Type 2 DM, CHF
Allergies: Sulfa drugs
Medications: Lisinopril, Metformin, Lasix

Admitted: Shortness of breath × 3 days
Code Status: Full Code
content.presentation: Patient sitting upright, appears anxious. Using accessory muscles to breathe. Oxygen saturation 89% on room air. Bilateral crackles in lung bases. 2+ pitting edema bilateral lower extremities. Weight up 8 lbs from baseline.
content.question: What is your priority nursing assessment?
considerations: Fluid volume excess - daily weights, I&O

content.title: Module 1 Key Takeaways
content.subtitle: Assessment Fundamentals Summary

points.title: Systematic Approach
points.description: Always use a consistent head-to-toe assessment framework to avoid missing critical findings

points.title: Four Techniques
points.description: Master inspection, palpation, percussion, and auscultation as your core assessment tools

points.title: Critical Thinking
points.description: Analyze findings in context of patient history and presenting symptoms

points.title: Documentation
points.description: Accurate, timely documentation protects you and supports continuity of care

content.next_topic: Module 2: Vital Signs and Hemodynamic Monitoring

content.title: Questions & Discussion
prompts: What assessment findings would prompt you to escalate care?
How do you prioritize multiple abnormal findings?
What are common assessment pitfalls for new nurses?
content.contact: Dr. Chen: s.chen@nursing.edu | Office Hours: MW 2-4pm

content.title: Cardiac Anatomy Reference
content.subtitle: Module 1 · Visual Reference
content.caption: Four-chamber heart diagram showing blood flow pathways and major vessels

content.title: Respiratory Distress Algorithm
content.subtitle: Module 2 · Clinical Decision Support
content.root_question: Is the patient in acute respiratory distress?

branches.label: Yes
branches.action: Position upright, apply O2, call for help, prepare for escalation

branches.label: No
branches.action: Complete respiratory assessment, monitor SpO2, reassess in 15 minutes

events.title: Evaluation
events.description: Assess response, document, monitor for adverse effects

content.title: Concept Mapping Activity
content.subtitle: Module 2 · Interactive Learning
content.placeholder_text: Use this space to create your patient care concept map

items.text: Verify patient identity using two identifiers
Confirm informed consent is signed and witnessed
Review allergies and update allergy band
Complete and document pre-procedure vital signs
Remove jewelry and dentures as appropriate
Complete Time Out before procedure begins

terms.definition: Heart rate greater than 100 beats per minute at rest. May indicate fever, pain, anxiety, dehydration, hypoxia, or cardiac pathology. Requires assessment of underlying cause.
Heart rate less than 60 beats per minute. May be normal in athletes or indicate heart block, medication effects, or increased intracranial pressure.
Decreased oxygen level in arterial blood (PaO2 < 80 mmHg). Distinguished from hypoxia, which refers to inadequate oxygen at the tissue level.
Difficulty breathing while lying flat, relieved by sitting upright. Classic sign of left-sided heart failure. Documented as number of pillows needed.

content.title: Quality Improvement: Fall Prevention
content.subtitle: Module 2 · Evidence-Based Practice
before_points: Limited staff awareness of high-risk patients
after_points: Morse Fall Scale on every admission

content.title: Critical Safety Alert
content.subtitle: Module 2 · Patient Safety
content.headline: High-Alert Medication Warning
content.message: Insulin, heparin, and concentrated electrolytes require independent double-check verification before administration. Never bypass this safety step.
action_items: Verify order with second licensed nurse
